text:
In this video, you’ll see how to 
analyze AWS Marketplace usage
and costs using the CUDOS Dashboard.

With this dashboard, you can locate 
pertinent AWS Marketplace usage and

cost data to support your analysis, 
evaluate aggregated Marketplace

spend across all your AWS accounts, 
and extract data or generate reports

for further analysis and 
distribution to internal teams.

The CUDOS Dashboard is one of six 
dashboards that make up the AWS
Cloud Intelligence Dashboard framework.

The CUDOS Dashboard combines deep 
analysis with resource-level granularity

to help you dive deep into cost 
and usage and fine-tune efficiency.

We’ll start in Amazon QuickSight, a 
cloud-powered business analytics

service that you can use to visualize, 
explore, and share insights from your data.
Let’s open the CUDOS Dashboard.

At the top of the screen 
are the tabs available to us.

The current selection is 
Month over Month Trends.

Beneath the tabs are five controls 
for filtering the underlying data.
Let’s look at each filter.
In this example, we have two payer accounts.
We have accounts.
We also have five linked account IDs.

Under the new Legal Entity filter, our 
sellers of record are listed alphabetically.
AWS Marketplace is our sole Billing Entity.

An AWS Marketplace section has 
recently been added as a feature
of the Month over Month Trends tab.
Let’s take a look.

The section includes two data 
visualizations representing AWS

Marketplace spend over a designated 
period, in this case, over the past six months.

The AWS Marketplace spend by Legal 
Entity visualization uses stacked bar charts.

Each stacked bar contains color-coded legal 
entities, along with their individual monthly cost.

The second visualization provides a 
detailed view of AWS Marketplace spend.

The two AWS Marketplace visualizations
 are logically linked, so user interaction
with one visualization updates the other.

Let’s test this by selecting a legal entity
from the legend in the first visualization.
We’ll select Zabbix.

The detailed view now displays 
only Zabbix usage and billing data.
Let's show the data for all entities again.

Next, let’s see how the tab controls 
can be used to view AWS Marketplace
spend for a specific entity.

This time we’ll choose a legal entity 
using the filter at the top of the page.
Let’s select F5 Networks.
Now only F5 Networks data is displayed.

The detailed view shows three F5 
products used by two AWS accounts.
Let’s revert to showing all our legal entities.

We can extract our AWS Marketplace 
spend information into an Excel file.

The Export to Excel option is available from 
the top-right corner menu of each visualization.
Let’s view the downloaded file.

This worksheet contains the same 
information that was shown in the
AWS Marketplace spend detailed view.

Let’s return to the CUDOS Dashboard 
and see how to generate a PDF report.
This time, we’ll export a report of the entire tab.

Let’s first make some quick adjustments
 to our tab format to see if the changes
are reflected in the report.
Now we’ll generate our PDF report.
Here’s the downloaded file.

The report shows all the visualizations 
on the Month over Month Trends tab.

The modification we made to the 
dashboard can be seen in the report.

Let’s return to Amazon QuickSight to 
see how to share our CUDOS Dashboard
with other organizational users.

The first step is to add any 
users we want to share with.

Let’s navigate to the Manage 
users page in QuickSight.
Next, we’ll invite a new user to this account.
Our user invitation has now been sent.
Let’s go back to the CUDOS Dashboard.

The second step is to share our 
dashboard with the newly added user.

We’ll provide our user with Viewer 
permissions and then add them.
Our user was added successfully.
Let’s switch to the user’s perspective.

The newly added user will receive a 
QuickSight welcome email with an
invitation to the account.
Once the user accepts the invitation

and registers with QuickSight, they can 
explore the shared CUDOS Dashboard.

You’ve just seen how to analyze 
AWS Marketplace usage and costs
using the CUDOS Dashboard.

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it’s your turn to try.
